discussion.content:
AD
"The audit user is not active by default. To activate it, log in as admin and run the set user audit command and provide a new password. "

comments.content: A&D is correct, Administrator keyword is blunder here. Each A&E answers has MUST keyword.

choices.A: The admin user must set the password for the audit account to log in to NSX Manager.
choices.B: The administrator must run the set audit user password <password> command.
choices.D: The audit user is disabled by default and must be enabled to log in to the NSX Manager.
choices.E: The administrator must run the set user audit password <password> command.
choices.C: The audit user has read-write access to the NSX Manager.

questions.question_text: Which statement is true regarding the audit user account? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Migrate vSphere port groups using the esxcli command line.
choices.B: Migrate vSphere port group through the NSX Manager API Calls.
choices.D: Migrate from the NSX Manager UI, go to Fabric -> Profile -> Uplink Profiles path.
choices.C: Migrate Networking from the vCenter Server.
choices.E: Migrate from the NSX Simplified UI> Click Transport Node > Configure NSX > PNIC Only Migration path.

questions.question_text:
An NSX administrator is migrating vSphere port groups configured in vSphere to N-VDS.
What are two migration options? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
You can migrate VMkernel interfaces by using the NSX-T Data Center Manager UI or NSX-T Data Center APIs
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX-T-Data-Center/2.4/installation/GUID-9E0AEE65-B24A-4288-B62E-4C71FB2B51BA.html
Correct answer is B & E - verified
B and E is correct answer
Yes, I think B,D are correct.

questions.question_text: What is the function of a domain in a NSX-T Data Center?

choices.D: defines the scope of transport nodes
choices.A: defines the scope of transport zones
choices.C: defines the scope of physical networks
choices.B: defines the scope of security policies and groups

discussion.content:
Update - B is indeed the correct answer. 

My previous answer was based on my thinking of Domain in the context of Transport Zones broadcast domain. 

So B is the correct answer - see NSX- T Admin Guide, page 116 through 166 under security topic. Current document last modified on 23 JUN 2020 VMware NSX-T Data Center 2.4

comments.content: No D is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: Which port is used by a transport node to communicate with NSX Manager in NSX-T Data Center 2.4?

discussion.content:
A is correct

TN port communication with NSX Manager 5671
TN port communication with management plane 1234
TN port communication with CCP (central control plane) 1235
https://ports.vmware.com/home/NSX-T-Data-Center

questions.question_text: Which three teaming policy modes are supported by NSX-T Data Center? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
BCF is correct, refer 2.4 guide : https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX-T-Data-Center/2.4/installation/GUID-50FDFDFB-F660-4269-9503-39AE2BBA95B4.html

On ESXi hosts: Load Balance Source MAC, Load Balance Source, and Failover Order teaming policies are supported
